title: Configure AppHub parameters
content:
After you have uploaded OO Containerized Helm chart to the repository, the associated application tile will appear on the Applications page. To upload a Helm chart, see Upload the application Helm chart.

To configure an application, complete the following steps:

  1. Click on an application tile, select a release version, and click Configure. Or, select the release version and click on the configure icon  .
    The application details appear on the Deployments page, which displays the parameters defined in the Helm chart.
  2. Configure the application parameters for each category tab that appears in the side menu. Each tab contains a series of fields and controls that enable you to configure the parameters that exist in the application’s Helm chart. When you are configuring an application, note the following:
    A tab with an   icon indicates that one or more parameters are incomplete or invalid.
    A tab with a check mark   indicates that all parameters are complete and valid.
    View help by hovering over parameter names.
    A toggle  represents a Boolean parameter that may show or hide additional parameters.
    Some parameters are immutable (or read-only) after successful deployment. These parameters are immutable because editing them could cause configuration issues.

    The side menu contains the following category tabs. Note that if there is nothing to configure for a category, the corresponding tab isn't displayed.
    General: Configure external access parameters, including host names, ports, and Docker register settings.
    Security: Configure the administrator password, override options for the user ID (UID) and group ID (GID), and upload trusted CA certificates.
    Databases: Configure database options and verify that the database connection information is valid. OPTIC AppHub displays the validation response sent by the database.
    Integrations: Configure OO integrations.
    Advanced: Configure advanced parameters.

  3. After you review each tab and configure all the required parameters:
    Click Deploy at the bottom of the page to deploy the application directly to Kubernetes
    Click Export icon at the top of the page to create a .zip file and deploy it via Helm CLI
    Click Save icon at the top of the page to finish configuring the deployment at a later time.

Configure General Settings

External Access Settings

External Access Settings
Configuration parameter in UI Description Default setting

External Access Host Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN)

Enter the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) of the external access host, which you provided during OMT install. Use this host to access OO.

External Access Port

Use this port to access all OO services.

Make sure to configure different port numbers on each instance of OO if you are deploying multiple instances of OO on the same Kubernetes cluster.

You may change it to 30443 for OO on RedHat OpenShift.

Make sure to configure a different port number than the port number of the external host that you entered in the config.json file used when installing OMT.

You can't change the port number after the initial deployment.  

9443

VERIFY AVAILABLE

Enter the port number of the OO external access host and click VERIFY AVAILABLE. If the port is available, you'll see the Available message. If the port is in use, you'll see the Port is not available message. Enter another port number and try again.

Docker Registry Settings

The Docker Settings are already populated with the default Registry and Organization name. It's recommended to use the same organization name and Docker registry that you used during OMT installation.

If you have configured the deployment with a different registry, enter the following details:

Docker Registry Settings
Configuration parameter Description Default setting

Docker Registry Name

Enter the URL containing the repository hostname and the port number of your docker registry.

For AWS, enter the URL containing the ECR repository hostname. For example:
788232947507.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com

localhost:5000

Docker Organization Name

Enter the organization name of the Docker repository.

hpeswitom

Kubernetes Provider

You can't change the Kubernetes provider after you deploy OO. Select Kubernetes Provider:

Kubernetes Provider
Configuration parameter Description Default setting
Kubernetes Provider Select one of the following Kubernetes: 
Embedded Kubernetes from the OPTIC Management Toolkit
Amazon EKS
Microsoft Azure AKS
RedHat OpenShift. 		 Embedded Kubernetes from the OPTIC Management Toolkit

Deployment size

Deployment size
Configuration parameter Description Default setting
Expected Deployment Size Select the deployment size. You can choose one of the following: 
Small, up to 5 tenants
Large, up to 20 tenants.		 Small

Configure Security

IdM Integration Details

Make sure the users already exist in IdM and have the right permissions.
IdM Integration Details
Configuration parameter Description Default setting

IdM External URL

Enter the FQDN to access IdM.

For eample: https:<domain_name>:<port>/idm-service)
OO Integration Admin User

Enter OO integration admin user name. To create OO integration admin user, see Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM.

 oo-integration-admin
OO Integration Admin Password

Enter the password that you set for the OO integration admin user (see Create OO integration admin user in the Service Management IdM).
IdM Transport User Enter IdM Transport username. To create IdM Transport user, see Get connection details for connecting to the Service Management IdM. idmTransportUser
IdM Transport User Password

Enter the password that you set for the IdM Transport user (see Get connection details for connecting to the Service Management IdM).
IdM Tenant Enter IdM tenant (IdM parent organization). sysbo

Upload TLS certificates

Make sure that you have all the required certificates in a temp folder. These certificates are required for enabling communications with components such as PostgreSQL, IdM, and others.

  1. In Upload TLS Certificates, click the box and then choose the TLS certificates  (CA or self-signed certificates for PostgreSQL) on your server. Or, you can drag the certificates into the box. Make sure the certificates are base64 encoded files. 
  2. Click VERIFY CERTIFICATE. This will verify if the certificates are valid and in the correct format.

Deploy CA-signed Server Certificate for Application Ingress

You can import your own CA signed server certificate when you deploy OO. You can import server certificates in Base64 encoded PEM format and private keys in Public-Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) #8 and PKCS #12 format.

  1. To import your own CA signed server certificate, enable Deploy CA-signed Server Certificate for Application Ingres.
  2. Select the format for certificate files as PKCS8 or PKCS12.
  3. To import the server certificate and PKCS #8 key:
    1. Select PKCS8.
    2. Upload the file containing the issuing Certificate Authority (CA) certificate.
    3. Upload the file containing the server certificate. Make sure the certificate is base64 encoded PEM format and the file contains all the intermediate certificates in the certificate chain.
    4. Upload the file containing the private key ( .key file). If the key file is encrypted, enter the password.
    5. Click VERIFY to validate the server certificate and key files.
  4. To import the server certificate and PKCS #12 key:
    1. Select PKCS12.
    2. Upload the file containing the issuing Certificate Authority (CA) certificate.
    3. Upload the PKCS12 File containing your TLS Key and Certificate. If the key file is encrypted, enter the password. 
    4. Click VERIFY to validate the server certificate and key files.

User ID and Group ID

You can't change UID and GID after the initial deployment.

User ID and Group ID
Configuration parameter Description Default setting

User ID (UID)
 

All containers in the deployment will run as this UID.

For RedHat OpenShift deployments, this value is retrieved from the Kubernetes namespace.

 1999

Group ID (GID)
 

All containers in the deployment will run as this GID.

For RedHat OpenShift deployments, this value is retrieved from the Kubernetes namespace.

 1999

Configure Database

External Database Settings

You can deploy the external PostgreSQL database in a single node configuration or a High Availability (HA) configuration.

External Database Settings
Configuration parameter Description

External PostgreSQL

External PostgreSQL is the only supported database type. 

Configure these parameters:

Database Hostname: Enter the FQDN of the external PostgreSQL database server.

Database Port for External Database: Enter the port number of the external PostgreSQL database server. Default port is 5432.

Database TLS: Use this toggle to enable secure communication with database services. It's enabled by default. When you disable Database TLS, select the checkbox below to acknowledge that you are aware of the associated security risks. It's recommended to enable TLS.

Database Creation

Database Creation
Configuration parameter Description Default value
Automatically create required databases

Enable this option to automatically create the required databases.

This option is applicable only for an on-premises deployment.

 Enabled
Database Superuser (Database Administrator) Enter the superuser (administrator) username for the database. postgres
Database Superuser Password Enter the superuser (administrator) password for the database.
VERIFY Click to validate the connection to the database server.

Database - OO Central

Database - OO Central
Configuration parameter Description Default value
Database Name (OO Central) Enter the name for OO Central database. oocentraldb
Database User Name (OO Central) Enter the username for OO Central database. oocentraldbuser
Database Password (OO Central) Enter the password for OO Central database.

Make sure that the password meets the following requirements:

  • Length must be at least 1 character
  • Length can't exceed 64 characters
  • Can't contain any whitespace characters
Confirm Database Password (OO Central) Confirm the password OO Central database.
VERIFY Click to validate the connection to the database server.

Configure Integrations

OO Integrations

OO Integrations
Configuration parameter Description Default value
Enable Service Management Integrations Enable this option to integrate Service Management with OO Enabled
Service Management FQDN Enter the FQDN of the Service Management host in the format: <domain_name>:<port>
Make sure you have followed the Upload TLS certificates section to ensure that OO can communicate properly with Service Management.

Configure Advanced Settings

Self Monitoring

The Self Monitoring option enables monitoring the health of the OO deployment like monitoring the availability, status, and performance of individual OO components. The self monitoring metrics are exposed through Prometheus and available for visualization through Grafana dashboards.

Self Monitoring
Configuration parameter Description Default value
Deploy Monitoring Configuration

Enabling monitoring configuration.

This is effective if Prometheus monitoring is deployed in the cluster.

 Enabled
Deploy Grafana Dashboard

Enable to view metrics in Grafana dashboard.

To view Grafana dashboard, go to <FQDN>:5443/grafana.

 Enabled

Configure Time Zone Settings

Configure Time Zone Settings
Configuration parameter Description Default value
Choose the desired Time Zone from the list below Define the time zone for OO logs based on your location. UTC

YAML EDITOR

The YAML EDITOR enables you to configure additional parameters that aren't exposed in AppHub UI but are available in the application Helm chart.

  1. Click YAML EDITOR.
  2. Add the additional parameters that you want to configure.
  3. Click SAVE.

It's recommended to use the AppHub UI for all configurations unless otherwise absolutely necessary.
